title: Riser Margin Calculation
question: On {{wellProfile.wellName}}, water depth is {{wellProfile.waterDepth.value}} {{wellProfile.waterDepth.unit}}, current TVD is {{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} {{currentSection.settingDepth.unit}}, and pore pressure gradient is {{scenario.porePressure}} ppg EMW. Seawater density is 8.55 ppg. Calculate the riser margin required.

calculation.formula: RM = (Pore Pressure - Seawater Density) × (Water Depth / TVD)
steps: Calculate pressure difference: Pore Pressure EMW - Seawater Density
Calculate depth ratio: Water Depth / Total TVD
Multiply to get Riser Margin in ppg
calculation.note: Riser margin ensures that if the riser is lost, seawater in the riser section won't allow formation to flow

feedback.correct: Correct. Riser margin = {{answer}} ppg. Your mud weight must be at least {{scenario.porePressure}} + {{answer}} = {{totalRequired}} ppg to maintain control if the riser is lost.
feedback.incorrect: Riser Margin = (PP - SW) × (WD / TVD). With PP={{scenario.porePressure}} ppg, SW=8.55 ppg, WD={{wellProfile.waterDepth.value}} m, TVD={{currentSection.settingDepth.tvd}} m, RM = {{answer}} ppg.
feedback.hint: Think of it this way: if you lose the riser, that column of mud becomes seawater. How much extra mud weight do you need below to compensate?

contextualTip: In {{wellProfile.waterDepth.value}} {{wellProfile.waterDepth.unit}} water depth, riser margin is significant. Always verify your MW exceeds pore pressure PLUS riser margin.
